Award.AwardTitle: The XENON1T Dark Matter Project: A Project Proposal from the US Institutions of the XENON Collaboration
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project addresses the question of the nature of galactic dark matter with a search for Weakly Interacting Massive Particles (WIMPs), using two-phase liquid xenon (LXe) Time Projection Chambers (LXeTPCs) as part of the XENON phased program. XENON100, building upon the success of the XENON10 prototype, represents the current state-of-the-art in WIMP search detectors. With a realistic discovery potential, XENON100 has already reached a world-leading sensitivity, and continues to accrue data at the Laboratori Nazionali del Gran Sasso (LNGS) in Italy towards its ultimate sensitivity reach. To fully probe a particularly favorable region of electroweak physics for WIMP dark matter in search of a first robust and statistically significant discovery, the next phase of the XENON program will be a detector at the ton scale - XENON1T. The worldwide race towards direct dark matter detection has been dramatically accelerated by the remarkable progress and evolution of LXeTPCs. They have shifted the scale of target mass from a few to tens of kilograms whilst simultaneously reducing both electronic and nuclear recoil backgrounds to extremely low levels. The XENON collaboration has demonstrated the effective scaling of LXeTPCs with phased detectors of increasing sensitivity of at least an order of magnitude, and is ready to move to the ton scale.

This award will provide funding to the US groups for the construction of the XENON1T detector, cryogenics infrastructure and calibration systems. This experiment is based on a TPC with 2.2 ton of LXe viewed by low radioactivity photomultiplier tubes. By exploiting the excellent self-shielding and 3D position resolution of a LXeTPC, by selecting existing low radioactivity detector materials and by placing the detector in a large active water shield and Cherenkov muon veto, the overall event rate within the fiducial target of 1.1 ton is estimated to be over a factor of 100 lower than the background measured in XENON100. This rate translates to less than one event per ton per year in the WIMP search region - an unprecedented low background level for a dark matter experiment.

Broader Impact: The XENON scientific goal to detect the missing mass in the Universe has all the ingredients to captivate the interests and imagination of students and the general public alike. The technological advances of this project can impact society in a number of ways: liquid xenon imaging detectors and related technologies find applications in several fields outside particle astrophysics, including homeland security and medical imaging research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
From various cosmological and astrophysical observations it is clear that Dark Matter is key to how galaxies form, and thus our very existence. Galaxies, including our Milky Way, consist of stars, planets and other ordinary matter held together by a much heavier but less dense "halo" of Dark Matter. No known particles can explain this Dark Matter. It is therefore imperative to test various hypotheses of what Dark Matter could be made of.

This award supported the construction of the XENON1T experiment, which at the time of writing is the leading experiment to test a variety of Dark Matter hypotheses. The experiment was the first in the field of Dark Matter direct detection to use a target at the ton-scale. It was built and run in collaboration with colleagues across the globe, but with significant leadership in the United States, and was substantially supported by this award. Funding allowed the construction of major components and multiple key systems that enabled the most sensitive search for Dark Matter particles ever conducted.

The XENON1T experiment is the most sensitive stage thus far of the XENON project. The project started with one of the first detectors to search for Dark Matter using the Time Projection Chamber technology, and continues to re-use much of the infrastructure and systems that were built under this award for the next stage, called XENONnT. The XENON collaboration is a large international endeavor bringing together more than 170 scientists representing 24 different nationalities from 27 institutions. US groups are responsible for key systems and lead the collaboration both in terms of contributions to the experimental hardware as well as the analysis of data from this experiment. Some systems supported by this award are pointed out in the figure below.

With the combined expertise from the US and international PIs, XENON1T was successfully designed, constructed and operated at the Italian Gran Sasso underground laboratory, as the most sensitive Dark Matter experiment ever build. A number of key technological innovations were developed under this award and implemented in the final experiment.

After construction finished, the experiment gathered calibration and science data for around two years, the longest ever accomplished for this type of detector. The data from XENON1T has been used for several physics analyses. Fourteen publications have so far been published by the collaboration in peer-reviewed journals. Results include the most stringent limit on WIMP Dark Matter over a wide WIMP mass range (with more than 600 citations), derived from an unprecedented exposure of 1 ton-years. A variety of other highly sensitive analyses were made possible by the excellent detector performance. For example, the high light yield of the detector enabled a low energy threshold and thus searches for sub-GeV Dark Matter as well as the recently proposed Migdal process. The collaboration was also able to discover double electron capture in the xenon-124 isotope. With a half-life 1.8x1022 years, a million million times the age of the Universe, this is the slowest radioactive decay ever measured and demonstrates the extreme sensitivity of XENON1T to rare events. Further, the energy resolution of XENON1T is the best of any comparable detector, demonstrating the potential of this technology for searches for neutrinoless double-beta decay, an important channel to help understand the origins of matter in the Universe. At the time of writing, data from XENON1T is still being analyzed and is expected to result in another handful of publications. The XENON1T project thus is the latest in a series of successful steps towards unraveling one of the Universe's greatest mysteries.
